content.content: I propose that the value of Dai be decoupled from the inflation factor that fiat currency has, specifically;  If the Dollar decreases, Dai would remain stable If the Fed succeeds in making the Dollar rise in value (which is difficult to sustain in the long term with the current macroeconomic outlook), Dai would rise along with the Dollar;   if the Dollar then has a mild correction, that correction would only take away part of Dai’s rise if the correction is larger than the rise, the entire rise would be subtracted, and the rest of the fall would not affect its value. This would be achieved by increasing the interest rate charged for issuing Dai enough for the value of Dai to offset the inflation of the Dollar. This may be counterproductive in short to medium term as less Dai will be in circulation due to some vault closures. Still, on the other hand, in the long term, institutions and individuals will borrow Dai and exchange their fiat money or other stablecoin for Dai, as they will be incentivized by the fact that inflation will not affect their capital, although not exactly, as inflation varies by location.  This improvement should increase its adoption. It would be the most exciting stablecoin in the crypto ecosystem and the one that investors who want to take profits from their portfolios in bull markets would opt for the most. Institutions and businesses would adopt it because if they are going to choose to spend or invest capital after half a year or more and want to be absent of most of the possible risks, they will be sure that the value of their equity will be the closest to the previous one than with any other crypto asset. According to my criteria, this idea would fit more with the concept of a stablecoin; the correct term for current stable coins should be parallel coins, as they parallel track their price. Disadvantages and risks:  Mild impermanent loss in Dai pairs with other stable currencies. Will probably slow down the adoption process in the short and medium-term; borrowers will be a bit less motivated to open a vault because of rising interest rates. It would be a bit less attractive for users borrowing Dai to buy and increase their position in different cryptos (the solution to this may be option B below).  If it is not feasible or optimal to make this modification to Dai, then option B could create a new stablecoin with this anti-inflationary feature, a Dai.Ex is an experimental Dai, something similar to how the Polkadot ecosystem does, which has its experimental layer “Kusama,” where all the tests are made with real money before putting the original and official project into operation. Dai could become an alternative or secondary haven of value to BTC in the best case. content.content: cryptenthusiastic:  What do you mean by “exchange rate risk”?   Suppose the GBP:USD exchange rate is 1.3. Suppose Monetalis takes a loan for 10M DAI with a collateral ratio of 150% to help financial solar generation worth 20M GBP. This vault can lose value in two ways. Suppose electricity gets cheaper and now the investment is only worth 15M GBP (only 19.5M USD). Suppose also that the GBP:USD exchange rate falls to 0.99 (e.g., Soros breaks the bank again ). Now the solar farm is worth sightly less than 15M USD and is subject to liquidation (less than 10M * 150%). If Monetalis financed the deal with a GBP-pegged version of DAI (i.e., DAI_GBP) then the GBP:USD exchange rate wouldn’t matter. The deal would get cheaper to finance because there would be no need to hedge against exchange rate risk.

No, I think you’re wrong about Bitcoin, I’m not an economist, but first what do you mean by price stability? Stability in terms of inflationary projection? All this has nothing to do with the concept of a store of value, largely there are more reasons why an asset is a store of value. If we look for more information on the previous point Bitcoin is a store of value, because it has all the main characteristics of a store of value and even has advantages over its traditional rival gold.  These are trust, durability, limited supply, divisible and transferable, uniformity and low storage cost. All these characteristics Bitcoin shares with gold, we can say that if it is a store of value. Now comes the best part the value, the value is something subjective, that is, it is the market that gives this value, the value comes from the people who trust and exchange with this asset, if this asset can be exchange it will have value. There is a lot of misrepresentation, but technically it could be defined that Bitcoin has an “intrinsic value”. Bitcoin is also Money, if we look for all the characteristics that make an asset to be money, we will see that Bitcoin fulfills all of them. In principle the most transcendental that are unit of account, medium of exchange and deposit or store of value. (Here we see that DAI also fulfills what it is to be money). Therefore, inflation is a maladjustment to the economic rules presented by “governments or the economy in general”. Inflation does not encourage growth, as does disinflation, which is the process we are in due to the passage of the coronavirus. All these imbalances and adjustments if they are in small portions are beneficial in the long run by balancing the economy, if they go to the extreme as in the case of deflation, they all generate destabilization, job losses, etc. In short, the economy is a cycle, a spiral that does not stop, that needs incentives to grow.

content.content: While I like the overall thinking and agree with the concern, I think we should keep to the idiom of “right tool for the right job”. The Dai is the right tool to peg to the dollar (and other currencies can apply as well), but the dollar is not inflation-protected. Inflation protection needs to be obtained in a another way, which is arguably best kept outside of Maker’s scope. A couple questions one would have to grapple with:  How do you define inflation? The CPI is one measure, many would contest it. Perhaps you want to maintain your USD buying ability vs real-estate (keep in mind, asset price “inflation” is not what the CPI measures) ? Commodities? Etc… No “correct” answer, but something to decide on. With #1 answered, how do you manage the risk and keep the protocol actually solvent for the prices it is supposed to correct for? Commodity futures are one way; making them interact with the crypto universe requires a bunch of work.  And so forth … much thinking and work here to be done. Bottom line, would love to see this concern solved but I don’t think Maker is the right tool for it.

content.content: Of course, it is understandable that volatility is something inherent to Bitcoin that may be corrected over the years, we agree on that, but of course there is another drawback to this “stability” relationship. You also have to change the unit of account and index it to something, for example, it is common for economists to index value from one currency to another, such as the dollar to a national currency. The specific issue there is what do we index to? With baskets of currencies the IMF’s Special Drawing Rights (SDR) comes to mind, it is also called paper gold because in a way it was intended to replace gold in transactions (I suppose it is used on certain occasions, maybe today not), it is simply a unit of account made up of several currencies in proportion that banks use as a reserve. Perhaps that model can be transferred in another way to build something crypto? The usability of these currencies if you manage to find their logic will be null, because despite being good references in terms of purchasing power or usability, you said it yourself Bitcoin is not usable in everyday life, we need that indexation to fiat to understand its value. It is good to debate a bit about this, I am very interested in these issues of “stability” and everything that has to do with monetary value.

content.content: Well, I think what you’re after is a currency that maintains buying power, rather than a denomination that is tied to a specific point-in-time in terms of USD buying power. E.g. you want your 100 Dai today to maintain the buying power of 100 USD as it is today, into the future, in perpetuity. The question is, what mechanisms would support it? Maker today has vaults, every loan is backed by properly collateralized assets which ensure the Dai is properly backed by sufficiently liquid USD-denominated assets. But if you deposit 1 ETH today and get 1500 CPI-Dai out, what mechanisms are there to back its value? What if ETH a year from now is $1500 while the CPI has gone up 10% ? Would the borrower be required to add up collateral to back the eroding buying power? I guess you could do that, but I don’t know how many borrowers would jump on that proposition. Another point -  a point-in-time reference for the USD buying power would have to be chosen. E.g. the CPI-Dai needs to represent the buying power of the USD at a particular moment in time, in order to be consistent. Otherwise if you deposit 1.01 USDC today and 1 Dai out, and I deposit 1.01 USDC 6 months from now and get 1 Dai out, they can’t be the “same” Dai as they have different values.
